Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Cyber-Eye: Empowering Learning through Remote Visualizations using Unmanned Aerial Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Cyberlearning and Future Learning Technologies Program funds efforts that will help envision the next generation of learning technologies and advance what we know about how people learn in technology-rich environments. This project explores the possibility of using Unmanned Aerial System (UAS) technology to support learning in construction engineering and management courses. Today, construction projects are becoming increasingly more complex. Students can learn about how projects unfold through field trips to build sites, but expense, timing, and safety precautions make it hard for students to see how a variety of construction projects unfold in time and space. This project will help students learn about construction projects by using unmanned aerial vehicles to record video of build sites over time; students and their teachers will be able to select important project aspects to view, and recorded video will help establish a case library for future students to see how the realities of job sites differ from contstruction documents.

This project focuses on facilitating the integration of procedural and configurational knowledge in construction and engineering management by supporting teaching of spatio-temporal constraints through case-based reasoning. The CyberEye system will be built and refined through iterative design of two components: first, the remote video and image generation component, which will integrate the aerial vehicle, a ground control station, and a communications and control platform to allow the cameras to capture desired aspects of the construction site; and second, a system to support learner access to the video, which will support creation of instructive cases, allow instructor and student planning and input of aerial missions (both synchronously and asynchronously), and archiving and reflective viewing for learners. The system will study both the learning outcomes and propose design principles using a four-iteration design-based research methodology implemented in college-level construction engineering courses. Semi-structured interviews and participant observation will be used to support formative evaluation, while pre-post experimental comparison will gauge the impact of the CyberEye intervention on student learning and especially spatial reasoning within the CEM domain for each iteration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cyber-Eye is an exploratory research project focused on facilitating the integration of procedural and configurational knowledge in construction and engineering management by supporting the teaching of spatio-temporal constraints through case-based reasoning. The research goal was to capitalize on the roles of situated learning and spatial cognition to develop and test a novel and intelligent educational intervention. The project outcomes enabled the following: (1) a better understanding of learning in Construction Engineering Management (CEM); and (2) development of an effective model that integrates Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAV), 'drones', technological innovations for education in CEM. Initial results of this project also demonstrated that the use of UAV output  in lieu of multiple job site visits, as learning materials in CEM contributes to informative experiences that can occur in a single, technology-enhanced learning environment and may better position the future engineering workforce for success.

To develop Cyber-Eye, the PIs advanced a theoretical framework for spatial and temporal ability development. This framework was used to design and build the bespoke Cyber-Eye technological intervention, which utilizes UAV aerial visualization in CEM problem-solving scenarios. In CEM, spatial information is defined as the way design components or resources are related to one another in a 3d space, and temporal information is the logic in a process, such as the order, sequences, and hierarchies of resources in construction tasks. 

Figure 1 shows a screenshot of the Cyber-Eye intervention. Using the technology, the PIs explored how the intervention enhances learners' perceptions and mediations of spatial and temporal information. Experiments used UAV technologies to enable learners to experience a unique, 'bird's-eye view' of in-situ contexts. Focused on enhanced perspectives of experiential learning scenarios, the images, when used to enhance pedagogical methods, facilitated the development of CEM skills that are essential for the success of project site activities, such as planning and goal prioritizing. Figure 2 shows the learning materials used in the experimentation.

Intellectual Merit: Cyber-Eye, which is the first such research and development of its kind, introduced a new approach that fuses UAVs with storage and retrieval technology to enable spatial-temporal skill development and to expand our conceptions of STEM education. The project explored how the use of the proposed technology enables a learner to expand her/his repertoire of actionable possibilities for contextual awareness of construction tasks and her/his resources to solve CEM problems. 

Broader Impacts included: It is expected that Cyber-Eye's results will have a broad, positive, and direct impact on the teaching and learning of CEM, specifically in engineering design thinking. Comprised of approximately 252,000 active sites that employ 6.5-million construction workers, today's construction industry accounts for one-tenth of the nation's GDP. Further research on the Cyber-Eye technological intervention and its widespread implementation will ensure that the US stays at the forefront of this economic activity. Cyber-Eye results responded to calls for research to effectively scaffold spatial ability development in STEM, as the development of this ability is strongly correlated with student success in STEM disciplines. The identification of effective learning conditions (a technology-enhanced learning environment as a resource in STEM education) will enable and expand fundamental research within the field of engineering education. This project addressed STEM as well as the 21st-century skill challenges associated with
spatial cognition and situated learning.
